description.narrative: IDH has focused the work of the landscape program on the concept of PPI: Production-Protection-Inclusion. IDH is implementing this concept through the development of PPI compacts in 11 landscapes in seven countries. These are agreements between public, private and civil society parties to enhance sustainable productive land and secure livelihoods in exchange for natural resource conservation. IDH convenes coalitions that develop these compacts. The compacts are based on participatory land-use planning, whereby land for production (increasing productivity), livelihoods (income diversification, resilience, access to markets) and protection (forest, water, soil) is clearly identified, and their related uses are agreed on by the landscape stakeholders and recognized by local and national governments. The compacts also include goals for each of the PPI components, a time-bound plan of action, clear definition of roles and responsibilities, and a budget for implementation. The compacts are the basis for the PPI Fund and other investors to invest in the landscapes, as well as the basis for regional sourcing by supply chain companies. This will result in coalitions that are self-sustaining, are linked to markets, and prove the business case for landscape-level interventions and investments.

receiver-org.narrative: Public and private organizations and partners associated with IDH through signed contracts and agreements for the development and implementation of specific activities and projects in the program sectors that IDH operates in.

Public and private organizations and partners associated with IDH through signed contracts and agreements for the development and implementation of specific activities and projects in the program sectors that IDH operates in.

title.narrative: # of producers/workers/community members trained on key subjects for sustainable production, environmental and social sustainability issues

description.narrative: It is important to capture the following information: The number of producers or workers or community members trained; Split by gender; The number and frequency of individual training events The topic of the training

title.narrative: Farmland area where trained practices are applied

description.narrative: Number of hectares (ha) of land where trained practices are applied; description of the category of practice applied and type of training/supporting activity implemented

comment.narrative: 123,097 ARS certification (through engagement of 46/48 soybean producers)
This is planned for Soy
296,643 hectares under good agricultural practices (181,916 hectares are compliant with FEFAC sourcing guidelines); 360 hectares under intensification; 389 hectares under restoration process

description.narrative: The amount of sustainable produced production (in Metric Tons) as the result of the training or services delivered by the program

comment.narrative: Expected volume of soybean production under RTRS certification to be maintained and expanded through the co-funding project with CAT Sorriso.

title.narrative: # of hectares where protection and restoration interventions are implemented

description.narrative: The number of hectares covered by protection and restoration interventions.

comment.narrative: This number corresponds to the total forest cover within the 250 farms participating in the Sustainable Production of Calves Program, considering the APP, Legal Reserve and native vegetation conserved above the law, from which: Juruena Valley = 5,511, Araguaia Valley = 15,196. Data related to 118 farms (55 Juruena and 63 Araguaia) verified through environmental visits and GIS info. Result for 2019 is lower than the target, because it took more time than expected to start up the deforestation-free cattle projects, and it took a while before farmers were enrolled in the projects.
Achieved through the project with CAT Sorriso (a farmer’s cooperative).

title.narrative: # of producers/workers/community enterprises reached by service delivery

description.narrative: The number of producers/ workers/community enterprises that have been offered services other than training within the scope of the program

comment.narrative: The project with CAT Sorriso (a farmers’ cooperative) will provide services to soy farmers to achieve and maintain RTRS certification, apply the Forest Code (i.e. ensuring the required areas on the property are protected and/ or restored), and to family farmers (smallholders in the Brazilian context) to improve their production of alternative commodities such as fruit, dairy, and nuts.

title.narrative: # of hectares where sustainable production/farm rehabilitation/sustainable intensification interventions are implemented

description.narrative: This indicator measures the area covered by actions that aim to achieve sustainable agriculture and/or forestry in the landscape / jurisdiction.

comment.narrative: This number corresponds to the total pasture area from the farms receiving technical assistance under the Sustainable Production of Calves Program, from which: Juruena Valley = 7,093, Araguaia Valley = 15,765. Data included are from 118 farms (55 Juruena and 63 Araguaia). Result for 2019 is lower than the target, because it took more time than expected to start up the deforestation-free cattle projects, and it took a while before farmers were enrolled in the projects.
Achieved through the project with CAT Sorriso (a farmer’s cooperative). See RA3.Output 2 Target 2020 explanation for details.

title.narrative: Result Area 1 - Change in business practice
Private sector (sustainability) investments in the program

description.narrative: The actual realized eligible private sector investments per program (in €)

comment.narrative: The two co-funding projects in Juruena Valley needed a little more start-up time than expected, leading to lower private sector spending than targeted.

description.narrative: Qualitative description about the embeddedness of sustainability at corporate level of companies/industry organizations/business platforms (this description should provide information on what have changed over the last reporting period in terms of their approach towards sustainability issues, including responsible sourcing and Protection Production Inclusion criteria in case of the landscapes programs)

comment.narrative: During 2018, the Sustainable Production of Calves Program was launched; one of the implementing partners is ACRIMAT, the Mato Grosso Cattle Ranching Association. The aim is that, during implementation, ACRIMAT can raise awareness of the socio-environmental issues within the beef supply chain, and can embed the lessons learned and expertise within the industry.

In October 2017, a supply chain model facilitating a more direct link between regions and end-buyers was discussed between the EU feed industry and Brazilian soy industry and producers (see narrative above), and it was agreed to continue these discussions based on the progress of the Sorriso Verified Sourcing Area pilot. IDH also convened a retail think-tank on responsible soy (see narrative above) to support direct sourcing from our responsible soy production areas. The group recognized that the buyer can either source RTRS or equivalent (1), FEFAC compliant (2), and/or work towards regional sourcing (3). This marks a change towards a continuous improvement approach. Discussions will continue in the above-mentioned Verified Sourcing Area working group.

IDH plans to provide post-investment technical assistance to COFCO, a commodity trader based in China. The project is focused on the expansion of soybean production over degraded pastureland, promoting compliance with the Forest Code. IDH’s role is to support the program design and provide pre- and post-investment technical assistance.

title.narrative: Business cases developed within the IDH program to show the potential of sustainable practices

description.narrative: The number and description of business cases that have been developed within the IDH program to demonstrate to the private sector the potential of sustainable practices adopted and implemented by other organizations

comment.narrative: 1 business case study on benefits of a landscape approach for cattle ranching; 2 field-level project-based business cases in progress on cattle intensification and regional sourcing of soy Related impact themes: mitigation of deforestation and smallholder inclusion.

1. In 2018 IDH has launched in Mato Grosso the Sustainable Production of Calves Program, that counts on EUR 1.6 million from IDH and EUR 1.9 million from Carrefour Foundation. The Program involves 457 calves producers (small-holders) distributed over 258 thousand ha in Juruena and Araguaia Valleys. The Program will supply beef traded under Carrefour’s own brand and covers 11 municipalities that are responsible for 40% of calves’ production in Mato Grosso State.

title.narrative: Representation and commitment of key-stakeholders in multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions

description.narrative: The indicator score is provided by a self-assessment performed by all stakeholders that are involved in the multi-stakeholder processes associated with the program or landscape. On an annual basis, all stakeholders that are active in the processes receive a request to complete a brief electronic questionnaire. The assessment is done through a set of statements focusing on the satisfaction, representation and commitment of the multi-stakeholder processes and coalitions as part of the IDH programs.

comment.narrative: * Paused in 2019

title.narrative: Satisfaction about the effectiveness of multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions associated with the program

description.narrative: The perceived satisfaction by the participating stakeholders (i.e. private sector, government, NGOs) of the multi-stakeholder process or coalitions in which they participate.

comment.narrative: * Paused in 2019

title.narrative: Changes at policy and regulatory level contributing to increased sustainability of commodity production and improved management of natural resources

description.narrative: Qualitative description explaining the background and progress of the changes in policies, regulations, and/or enforcement of these as a result of IDH interventions

comment.narrative: Mato Grosso state PRA legislation was launched. The PCI Coalition was formalized with a decree. The government decided to continue with the SICAR system.

Start of the PCI facility building on the PCI decree published in 2016 (which made the PCI strategy official and ordered the instalment of a committee to oversee the implementation of PCI) as well as on the PCI implementation roadmap (see result below for the KPI on “landscape plans developed”). The PCI facility would enable the PCI to receive donor funds committed by Germany (KfW) and the United Kingdom (BEIS). The role of IDH is to support this process with a legal advisor that considers the best options for legal and fund structures.

The 3 changes in policy and regulatory level achieved in 2019 are: 1) State decree recognizing the PCI Institute, 2) Municipal decree in Barra do Garças recognizing the PCI regional compact, 3) New monitoring system for deforestation and degradation adopted by SEMA
a) Juruena Municipality Decree about the PCI regional compact, b) Barra do Garças Municipality Decree about the PCI regional compact

description.narrative: The identification and stage of development of plans that are developed by a coalition of stakeholders in the landscape in which IDH operates.

comment.narrative: 1 additional PPI compact
1 additional PPI compact in Balsas (MA)
